lead_paragraph: A group of prominent academics has accused the company of reverting to secretive ways over its use of forced labor during World War II.

byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Berlin, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.
byline.original: By ALISON SMALE and JACK EWING

headline.print_headline: Volkswagen Parts Ways With the Historian Who Chronicled Its Nazi Past
headline.main: Volkswagen Parts Ways With the Historian Who Chronicled Its Nazi Past

snippet: A group of prominent academics has accused the company of reverting to secretive ways over its use of forced labor during World War II....
abstract: Mystery surrounding abrupt end to contract between Volkswagen and historian Manfred Grieger, who was integral in company's revelation of its Nazi past, has complicated company's efforts to regain trust in wake of scandal regarding its cover-up of diesel emissions; group of prominent German academics have publicly criticized company for ending of contract, which appears to have been precipitated by Grieger's critical review of study on World War II labor practices of VW subsidiary Audi.
